awd_titl_txt: Growth and Interface Physics of Epitaxial Graphene
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is co-funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) and Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Programs in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).
Technical: This research project is on the growth and interface physics of epitaxial graphene grown on silicon carbide (SiC) substrates. Epitaxial graphene is a two-dimensional electron system with coherence lengths that can exceed one micrometer at a temperature of 4 K, and with high electron mobilities, even at room temperature. Multiple layers of graphene grown on the silicon-terminated face of silicon carbide stack in a manner similar to graphite. On the carbon-terminated face of SiC, the growth of multiple layers is more unusual, with azimuthal rotation from one graphene layer to the next. This has the effect of reducing the interaction between graphene layers. However, the origin of this rotational stacking (and the electronic decoupling) is not known with certainty. Using surface science methods (including characterization via low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and related techniques), new growth methods for epitaxial graphene on SiC will be developed and quantified. The physics of interfaces of graphene based materials of different dimensionalities, as well as intrinsic graphene properties, will be studied in this project. Two dimensional interfaces include the graphene/SiC interface, the interface between rotated graphene layers, and the metal/graphene interface. A one-dimensional interface of interest is the graphene p-n junction, where electron carriers on one side transmit into hole states on the other. The electronic properties of one-dimensional (in-plane) grain boundaries separating graphene lattices with different orientation are also investigated, and likewise for step edges and lithographically-defined nanoribbons. "Zero-dimensional interfaces" comprise point defects in graphene and graphene quantum dots. The quantum dot of most concern for our work is a potential-well induced in graphene by the measurement itself.
Non-Technical: This research concerns the development of graphene, a new material with potential applications to low-power, nanometer-scale electronic devices. In this project, graphene refers to one-atom-thick and few-atom-thick carbon films. The overall project ties research to education at different levels via participation in programs designed by education professionals. These programs often focus on the preparation of students traditionally underrepresented in the physical sciences. For example, Georgia high school teachers experience research in the PI's lab for 7-8 weeks each summer through an on-campus Research Experience for Teachers program. The experience enables them to bring modern science to the classroom.

Intellectual Merit

The two-dimensional (2D) geometry of materials like graphene--an atomic layer of carbon atoms in a honeycomb pattern--restricts electron motion to a plane, and further modifications (e.g., creating a 1D ribbon) may guide electrons in a manner similar to light through an optical fiber. Developing methods to create 2D materials and nanostructures is valuable for future electronic devices that may exploit the wave properties and interactions of electrons in two (or fewer) dimensions. In this research, we studied the growth of graphene on a semiconductor substrate (silicon carbide or SiC) in order to understand how the graphene forms at high temperatures and how to control the growth. We also discovered that naturally-occurring strain in some graphene-on-SiC nanostructures can affect electrons in a way that mimics the effect of a high magnetic field. Finally, we explored the possibility to form silicene, the silicon analog of graphene.

Graphene is induced to form on a SiC crystal by heating to temperatures above 1300 K. At the growth temperature, silicon (Si) atoms leave the surface, making it carbon rich. Diffusing carbon atoms bond to form a graphene honeycomb, whose orientation is determined by the ordered SiC crystal facet (the (0001) facet). We found that the graphene growth rate can be controlled by the introduction of a silicon-containing gas (silane, SiH4) into the vacuum furnace. Silicon from the silane dynamically replaces evaporated Si, thus slowing the carbon-enrichment of the surface, which slows graphene growth. We developed a kinetic model and showed that it explains our experimental measurements of the growth rate. By characterizing the furnace-dependent parameters once, the model can be used to predict graphene growth rates under different conditions and for different furnaces.

We also studied graphene growth on not-quite-flat ("vicinal") surfaces of SiC, to understand the role of pre-existing atomic steps in the substrate (actually, two-atom Si-C bilayer steps).  The density of steps was controlled by polishing the SiC facet at an angle (the vicinal angle) from its ideally-flat (0001) facet. A larger vicinal angle produces a higher density of bilayer steps. After heat treatment to grow graphene, we found that steps crowd together into bunches, with the step-bunch sizes dependent on the vicinal angle. To characterize many angles at the same growth parameters, we created shallow dimples in the SiC(0001) facet by grinding and polishing. The crystals were then heat-treated under chosen silane pressures. Our experiments showed that, for small vicinal angles, the step bunch sizes scale approximately as the square-root of the angle. This observation led to the development of a rate-equation model for the graphene growth and step bunching, which, after numerical solution, reproduces the observed scaling. The results also imply that Si evaporation occurs predominantly at step edges. These insights and modeling are valuable for the development of controlled graphene growth on SiC.

The carbon-enriched step bunches (a.k.a. sidewalls, or sidewall nanofacets) present an opportunity to create quasi-1D nanostructures. Stopping the growth process at an early stage, we created "sidewall nanoribbons" of graphene on the step bunches, with limited overgrowth onto the flat (0001) facets. These nanoribbons hug the step bunch, and perhaps could guide electron waves. We discovered that the distribution of electron energies undergoes substantial rearrangement within the region where graphene transitions from the flat SiC(0001) facet to the sidewall. In fact, spectroscopic features that we observe (using scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy) are like those created by a large magnetic field applied perpendicular to the graphene plane. These "pseudo Landau Level" features are seen in other forms of strained graphene; in our case, we showed that it is shear strain which is dominant.

As part of our studies of graphene growth, we also catalogued metastable 2D phases of Si on SiC, grown by depositing Si atoms from silane.  One of these newly-discovered 2D periodic phases ("√43x√43") is intriguing because its size and orientation are close to expectations for an atomic layer of sp2-bonded silicon (silicene). Further investigation ultimately showed that the phase is not silicene, but predominantly sp3-bonded Si, for which we proposed a structural model. This phase could prove useful for the development of silicon-on-SiC electronics.

Broader Impacts

In addition to the impact on professional and technical fields described above, under this NSF support:

* Four PhDs were awarded with partial support from this grant (URIs: http://hdl.handle.net/1853/50205; http://hdl.handle.net/1853/54964; http://hdl.handle.net/1853/58197; http://hdl.handle.net/1853/63634 ). Three students became semiconductor- or data-scientists in the US, one advances STEM Education in Taiwan.

* Four Georgia Tech undergraduates learned to apply their "book learning" to research challenges, both scientific and technical.

* Three Georgia high school teachers gained laboratory research experience, producing lesson plans which relay the excitement of research to their students.

* Outreach activities--e.g., Career Day presentations at a local high school, lab tours, Society of Physics Students projects--encouraged participation of underrepresented groups in STEM.
